column2: and told the man his aunt would pay for all the broken things. Then he took his naughty pet
column3: and started to go home and tie him up
column4: for it was plain this monkey was not to be trusted. But as soon as they got out
column5: Jocko ran up a tree and dropped on to a load of hay passing underneath. Here he danced and pranced
column7: throwing off the man's coat and rake
column8: and eating some of the dinner tied up in a cloth. The crusts of bread and the bones he threw at the horse; this new kind of whip frightened the horse
column9: and he ran away down a steep hill
column10: and upset the hay and broke the cart. Oh
column11: such a time! It was worse than the candy scrape; for the man swore
column13: and people said the monkey ought to be shot
column14: he did so much mischief. Jocko didn't care a bit; he sat high up in a tree
column17: and was so droll that people couldn't help laughing at him.
